sentences.sentence: But the step-mother said, “No, Cinderella, you have no clothes and you cannot dance; you would only be laughed at( 被嘲笑 ).”
And as Cinderella wept( 哭泣 ) at this, the step-mother said, “If you can pick two dishes of lentils( 小扁豆 ) out of the ashes( 灰烬 ) for me in one hour, you shall go with us.”
And she thought to herself, “That she most certainly cannot do.”
When the step-mother had emptied the two dishes of lentils amongst the ashes, the girl went through the back-door into the garden and cried,
“You tame( 听话的 ) pigeons( 鸽子 ), you doves( 鸽子 ), and all you birds beneath( 在...下方 ) the sky, come and help me!”
Then the white pigeons came in by the kitchen-window, and then the doves, and at last all the birds beneath the sky, came flying and crowding in( 大批涌入 ), and landed in the ashes.
And the pigeons nodded with their heads and began pick, pick, pick, pick, and the rest began also pick, pick, pick, pick, and gathered( 收集 ) all the good grains( 颗粒 ) into the dish.
In less than half an hour they had finished, and they all flew out again.
Then the girl took the dish to her step-mother, and was happy.
She believed that now she would be allowed to go with them to the festival.
But the step-mother said, “All this will not help you; you cannot go with us, for you have no clothes and cannot dance; we should be ashamed of( 为...感到羞耻的 ) you!”
On this she turned her back on Cinderella, and hurried away( 匆匆离开 ) with her two proud daughters.
As no one was now at home, Cinderella went to her mother’s grave( 坟墓 ) beneath the tree, and cried,
“Shiver( 颤抖 ) and quiver( 发抖 ), little tree,
Silver and gold throw down over me.”
Then the birds threw a gold and silver dress down to her, and slippers( 鞋 ) decorated( 装饰 ) with silk and silver.
She put on the dress as fast as she could, and went to the festival.
Her step-sisters and the step-mother however did not know her, and thought she must be a foreign princess( 公主 ), for she looked so beautiful in the golden dress.
They never once thought of Cinderella, because they believed that she was sitting at home in the ashes.
The prince( 王子 ) went to meet her, took her by the hand, and danced with her.
He would dance with no other girl, and never let go of her hand, and if anyone else came to invite her, he said, “This is my partner( 舞伴 ).”
She danced till it was evening, and then she wanted to go home.
But the King’s son said, “I will go with you and keep you company( 陪伴你 ) ,” because he wanted to see the beautiful girl’s family.
She escaped( 逃走 ) from him, however, and ran into the pigeon-house.
The King’s son waited until her father came, and then he told him that the girl had run into the pigeon-house.
The old man thought, “Can it be Cinderella?”
They searched the pigeon-house but no one was inside it.
And when they got home Cinderella lay in her dirty clothes among the ashes.
She had jumped quickly down from the back of the pigeon-house and had run to the little tree.
Then she had taken off( 脱掉 )  her beautiful clothes and the birds had taken them away again, and then she went to the kitchen and sat among the ashes in her gray dress.
Next day when the festival began again, her parents and the step-sisters left once more. Cinderella went to the tree and said:
“Shiver and quiver, little tree,
Silver and gold throw down over me.”
Then the birds threw down a much more beautiful dress than on the previous day.
And when Cinderella appeared at the festival in this dress, everyone was astonished( 感到震惊的 ) at her beauty.
The King’s son had waited until she came, and instantly( 马上 ) took her by the hand and danced with no one but her.
When others came and invited her, he said, “She is my partner.”
When evening came she wished to leave, and the King’s son followed her and wanted to see into which house she went.
But she ran away( 逃走 )  from him, and into the garden behind the house.
In the garden was a beautiful tall tree on which hung the most magnificent( 极好的 ) pears.
She climbed so nimbly( 敏捷地 ) between the branches( 树枝 ) like a squirrel( 松鼠 ) that the King’s son did not know where she had gone.
He waited until her father came, and said to him, “The beautiful young girl has escaped from me, and I believe she has climbed up the pear-tree.”
The father thought, “Can it be Cinderella?” and ordered the servant to bring the ax( 斧头 ) and cut the tree down, but no one was in it.
And when they went to the kitchen, Cinderella lay there amongst the ashes, as usual.
She had jumped down on the other side of the tree, had taken the beautiful dress to the birds, and put on( 穿上 )  her old kitchen dress.
